author: Mohamed Imranullah S
text:
The Madras High Court Bench here on Thursday wondered why the State Government was hesitant to argue a writ appeal filed by it against the imposition of a dress code for entry into temples administered by the Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments (HR&CE) Department. Justice S. Vaidyanathan had prescribed the dress code in an order issued late last year.

A Division Bench of Justices V. Ramasubramanian and N. Kirubakaran directed its Registry to list the State appeal for hearing on Monday along with two other petitions — one filed by P. Suganthi, State general secretary of the All India Democratic Women’s Association (AIDWA) and another by G. Sarika of Southern Districts Women’s Federation — seeking leave of the court to file appeals. Earlier, Special Government Pleader VR. Shanmuganathan told the court that the Registry has been requested to list the appeal for admission on Tuesday to facilitate the appearance of Advocate General. However, the judges asked him to make his submissions on Monday and directed U. Nirmala Rani and A. Rajini, counsel for private appellants, to serve their papers on him in the meantime.

Disposing of a writ petition, seeking permission for cultural programmes in view of a temple festival in Tiruchi district, on November 26, Justice S. Vaidyanathan had ordered that from January 1, men should wear “dhoti or pyjama with upper cloth or formal pants and shirts” and women “sari or half sari with blouse or churidhar with upper cloth” to temples. He also ordered that children could go in “any fully-covered dress.”
title: Dress code: HC to hear appeal on Monday
